facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 146 of 1955 before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 146 of 1955. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated February 10, 1953,

facts.text: Appeal from Bombay High Court judgment dated February 10, 1953 in Appeal No. 953 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated February 10, 1953, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 953 of 1951, arising out of the judgment and decree dated November 36,1951,

facts.text: High Court appeal arose from trial court judgment dated November 30, 1951 in Special Suit No. 76 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and decree dated November 36,1951, of the Court of Joint Civil Judge, Senior Division, Poona, in Special Suit No. 76 of 1950.

facts.text: Trial court is Court of Joint Civil Judge, Senior Division, Poona.

anchor.surface_text: of the Court of Joint Civil Judge, Senior Division, Poona, in Special Suit No. 76 of 1950. D. Banaji, R. A. Gagrat and G. Gopalakrishnan, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant is a public limited company registered under Indian Companies Act, 1913.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS, C. J.-The appellant is a public limited companypany registered under the Indian Companies Act, 1913.

facts.text: Appellant is lessee of four cinema houses in Poona: Minerva, The Globe, Sri Krishna and The Nishat.

anchor.surface_text: It is a lessee of four cinema houses situate within the municipal limits of Poona City known respectively as Minerva , The Globe , Sri Krishna and The Nishat .

facts.text: Appellant exhibits cinematograph films, both foreign and Indian, in the four houses.

anchor.surface_text: It exhibits cinematograph films, both foreign and Indian, in the said four houses. The respondent, a body companyporate,

facts.text: Respondent governed by Bombay District Municipal Act, 1901 up to June 8, 1926.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, a body companyporate, was governed by the Bombay District Municipal Act, 1901  Bom. III of 1901  up to June 8, 1926,

facts.text: Respondent governed by Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925 up to December 29, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: and from then by the Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925  Bom. XVIII of 1925  up to December 29, 1949,

facts.text: Respondent thereafter governed by Bombay Provincial Municipal Corporation Act, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: and, thereafter, by the Bombay Provincial Municipal Corporation Act, 1949  Bom. LIX of 1949 .

facts.text: With effect from October 1, 1920, respondent levied tax of Rs. 2 per day as license fee on owners and lessees of cinema houses.

anchor.surface_text: With effect from October 1, 1920, the respondent, with the sanction of the Government of Bombay levied on the owners and lessees of cinema houses within the limits of the erstwhile province of Bombay a tax of Rs. 2 per day as license fee.

facts.text: Rules for levy and collection of the tax were framed by respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Rules for the levy and companylection of the said tax were framed by the respondent.

facts.text: Rules amended on or about June 3, 1941, enhancing tax from Rs. 2 per day to Re. 1 per show.

anchor.surface_text: Those rules were amended on or about June 3, 1941, enhancing the tax from Rs. 2 per day to Re. I per show.

facts.text: Rules revised on or about June 9, 1948, enhancing tax to Rs. 5 per show.

anchor.surface_text: The rules were again revised on or about June 9,1948, under which the tax was enhanced from Re. I per show to Rs. 5 per show.

facts.text: Tax collected at Rs. 5 per show rate at all material times.

anchor.surface_text: At all material times the tax was being companylected at the last mentioned rate.

facts.text: Appellant has been making payments of the tax under protest since becoming lessee.

anchor.surface_text: Ever since the appellant became a lessee of the said cinema houses, the appellant has been making payments of the said tax under protest.

facts.text: Appellant filed suit No. 76 of 1950 on or about March 31, 1950 after statutory notice.

anchor.surface_text: After giving the necessary statutory numberice to the respondent, the appellant, on or about March 31,1950, filed a suit in the Court of the Civil Judge, Senior Division, Poona, being Suit No. 76 of 1950,

facts.text: Suit sought declaration that tax levy from 1920 invalid, enhancements 1941 and 1948 invalid, resolutions ultra vires, injunction, refund.

anchor.surface_text: against the respondent for a declaration that the levy and imposition of the said tax with effect from October 1, 1920, were invalid and illegal that the enhancement in the rates of the tax with effect first from June 3, 1941, and then June 9, 1948, was invalid and illegal and that the resolutions passed and rules framed in companynection with the levy, imposition, enhancement and companylection of the said impugned tax were invalid, illegal and ultra vires, for a permanent injunction restraining the defendants from levying or recovering and or increasing and enhancing the said tax and for refund to the appellant of the amounts of the tax companylected from it and for companyts of the suit and interest.

facts.text: Trial court judgment dated November 30, 1951 held tax validly levied but enhancements in 1941 and 1948 illegal, suit not barred, decreed injunction and refund of Rs. 27,072 with interest and costs.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated November 30, 1951, the trial companyrt held that the said tax was validly levied and imposed, but that the increase and enhancement thereof in 1941 and 1948 were illegal and ultra vires. and that the suit was number barred under the Acts governing the respondent. The trial companyrt decreed the suit in part by issuing an injunction restraining the respondent from levying, recovering or companylecting the tax at the enhanced rate and passing a decree against the respondent for refund of a sum of Rs. 27,072 with interest and companyts.

facts.text: High Court by judgment dated February 10, 1953 reversed trial court and dismissed suit with costs, dismissed cross-objections.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent preferred an appeal and the appellant filed cross objections. But the High Court by its judgment and decree dated February 10, 1953, reversed the judgment of the trial companyrt and dismissed the suit of the appellant with companyts throughout. The appellants cross objections were also dismissed.

facts.text: High Court granted leave to appeal to Supreme Court on December 10, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On December 10, 1953, the High Court granted leave to the appellant to appeal to this Court from the said judgment.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered January 16, 1959 by DAS, C.J.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. January 16. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS, C. J.-

facts.text: Trial court held enhancements illegal and ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: the trial companyrt held that the said tax was validly levied and imposed, but that the increase and enhancement thereof in 1941 and 1948 were illegal and ultra vires.

facts.text: High Court rejected appellant's contention on delegation under s.59(1)(xi).

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves in agreement with the High Court in rejecting this companytention.

facts.text: Supreme Court held s.59(1)(xi) constitutional, no excessive delegation.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the impugned section did lay down a principle and fix a standard which the municipalities had to follow in imposing a tax and the legislature cannot, in the circumstances, be said to have had abdicated itself and, therefore, the delegation of power to impose any other tax cannot be struck down as being in excess of the permissible limits of delegation of legislative functions.

Section 59 of the Bombay District Municipal Act 1901 provided that subject to any general or special orders which the State Government might make in that behalf any municipality  a  after observing the preliminary procedure required by s. 60, and  b  with the sanction of the authority therein mentioned, might impose for the purposes of that Act any of the taxes mentioned in that section. After enumerating ten specific heads of taxes, which a municipality companyld levy a residuary category was set forth in cl.  xi  in the words following- Any other tax to the nature and object of which he approval of the Governor in, Council shall have been obtained prior to the selection companytemplated in sub-clause  1  of clause  a  of section 60 .

concepts.interpretation: Lays down a principle and fixes a standard for municipalities to follow in imposing tax; delegation not excessive as power limited to purposes of Act, related to municipal duties, guided by prior items and subject to Governor-in-Council approval.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: Governor- in-Council might mean the Governor in Executive Council or the Governor in Legislative Council. If the reference in s. 59 1  xi  is to the

concepts.unlisted_description: Provision authorizing municipalities to impose taxes including residuary cl.(xi) with prior approval.

concepts.unlisted_description: Entry covering tax on cinemas; appellant claimed it was entry 46 (trade tax) limited by s.142A.

anchor.surface_text: but is really a tax on the appellants trade or calling referred to in entry 46 and that, therefore, the amount of tax cannot under s. 142-A of the Government of India Act, 1935 exceed Rs. 100 per annum.

concepts.unlisted_label: List II Entry 46, Government of India Act 1935
concepts.unlisted_description: Tax on trade or calling, alleged limit Rs.100 p.a. under s.142A.

anchor.surface_text: the amount of tax cannot under s. 142-A of the Government of India Act, 1935 exceed Rs. 100 per annum. This point need number detain us long, for it is companyered by us in the appellants other appeal No. 145 of 1955.

concepts.unlisted_description: Limit on provincial tax on professions/trades.

concepts.interpretation: Delegation valid if lays down principle and standard; here limited by Act's purposes, municipal duties, ejusdem generis indication, Governor approval; not abdication.

That section runs as follows- Power to suspend 60 1 Subject to the requirements of cl- reduce or abolish ause  a of the proviso to section any existing tax 58 municipality may except as otherwise provide in clause provided in clause  b  of the proviso to section 103 at any time for any sufficient reason, suspend, modify or abolish any existing tax by suspending, altering or rescinding any rule prescribing such tax.

concepts.interpretation: 'Modify' includes enhancement/increase, not just reduction; legislature changed 'reduce' to 'modify' intentionally; marginal note 'reduce' inadvertent and does not control plain language.
concepts.unlisted_description: Power to suspend, modify or abolish existing tax.

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, the marginal numbere cannot affect the companystruction of the language used in the body of the section if it is otherwise clear and unambiguous  see Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay v. Ahmedbhai Umarbhai Co., Bombay   1 .

concepts.interpretation: Marginal notes cannot affect construction if body language clear; here 'reduce' in marginal inadvertent.
concepts.unlisted_description: Principle that marginal notes do not control plain meaning of section.

arguments.claim: Under cl. (xi) of s. 59(1), the enhancements of the rates of the tax in 1941 and 1948 were illegal as the municipality had no power to do so under s. 60 of the Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925; 'modify' means reduce based on marginal note and root meaning.

anchor.surface_text: The last point urged by learned companynsel for the appellant is that, under el.  xi  of s. 59 1 , the enhancements of the rates of the tax in 1941 and again in 1948 were illegal in that the municipality had numberpower to do so under the Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925.

arguments.claim: Municipality's taxing power cannot exceed that of the provincial legislature itself, e.g., cannot impose income tax.

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves in agreement with the High Court in rejecting this companytention. In the first place, the power of the municipality -cannot exceed the power of the provincial legislature itself and the municipality cannot impose any tax, e.g., income tax which the provincial legislature companyld number itself impose.

arguments.claim: Taxes under s.59 must be for purposes of the Act, implementing municipal obligations and functions in Ch. VII, with reasonable relation to duties like those in s.54 (lighting, water).

anchor.surface_text: In the next place, s. 59 authorises the municipality to impose the taxes therein mentioned for the purposes of this Act . The obligations and functions cast upon the municipalities are set forth in ch. VII of the Act. Taxes, therefore, can be levied by the municipality only for implementing those purposes and for numberother purpose.

arguments.claim: Items (i) to (x) in s.59(1) indicate the kind and nature of taxes authorised, even if ejusdem generis strictly inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: In the third place, although the rule of companystruction based on the principle of ejusdem generis cannot be invoked in this case, for items  i  to  x  do number, strictly speaking, belong to the same genus, but they do indicate,

arguments.claim: Municipality's taxing power under s.59(1)(xi) subject to approval of Governor-in-Council, preventing abdication.

anchor.surface_text: Finally, the provincial legislature had certainly number abdicated in favour of the municipality, for the taxing power of the municipality was quite definitely made subject to the approval of the Governor-in-Council.

holdings.text: The contention that the tax is not covered by entry 50 but by entry 46 of List II to the Government of India Act, 1935, with a limit of Rs. 100 per annum under s. 142A, is rejected as already covered in the appellant's other appeal No. 145 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: This point need not detain us long, for it is covered by us in the appellants other appeal No. 145 of 1955.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Point conclusively decided in companion appeal No. 145 of 1955 against the appellant.

holdings.text: Section 59(1)(xi) of the Bombay District Municipal Act, 1901 is constitutional and does not involve excessive delegation of legislative power as it lays down a principle and fixes a standard for municipalities to follow.

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves in agreement with the High Court in rejecting this contention. In the first place, the power of the municipality cannot exceed the power of the provincial legislature itself and the municipality cannot impose any tax, e.g., income tax which the provincial legislature could not itself impose.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Delegation limited by provincial powers, Act's purposes (Ch. VII, s.54), indicative prior taxes (ejusdem generis-like), and Governor-in-Council approval; lays down principle/standard, no abdication.

holdings.text: Enhancements of the tax rates in 1941 and 1948 are valid under s. 60 of the Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925, as 'modify' includes increase or enhancement, not limited to reduction.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Marginal note 'reduce' does not control clear body text 'modify' (precedent: CIT v. Ahmedbhai); legislature intentionally changed prior 'reduce' (s.67 of 1901 Act) to 'modify'; root meaning and context support inclusion of enhancement.
